newsitem.title: USA: Computer Assoc. posts earnings vs. year-ago loss.
newsitem.headline: Computer Assoc. posts earnings vs. year-ago loss.

text.p: Computer Associates International Inc., which agreed last week to buy Cheyenne Software for $1.2 billion, Wednesday reported earnings of $223 million for the latest quarter, compared with a loss a year ago.

The biggest independent maker of software for mainframe computers said the earnings amounted to 59 cents a share for its second quarter ended Sept. 30, compared with a loss of $637.2 million, or $1.76 a share, in the 1995 quarter.

The year-ago figures included a pretax charge of $1.3 billion related to Computer Associates' $1.8 billion purchase of Legent Corp., another mainframe software company, last year. Excluding the charge, earnings in the 1995 quarter were $170.9 million, or 45 cents a share.
Results for the latest quarter beat expectations on Wall Street, but CA stock sank, apparently on concerns that the Cheyenne acquisition would dilute CA's earnings in the short run.
It fell $2.50 to $63.25 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Sales grew 22 percent to $990.1 million in the quarter from $812.3 million.
The company cited strength in sales of computer software for businesses, including database management, application development, manufacturing and financial applications.
While CA is a big player in mainframe software, it has been moving aggressively into the business of selling software for corporate networks of personal computers.
The agreement to buy Cheyenne, a maker of data storage, communications and anti-virus software, was a step in that direction, industry analysts said.
While the company said when it announced the Cheyenne acquisition on Oct. 7 that it would not affect earnings, some analysts questioned the deal.

Several analysts said CA might be overpaying, and at least one said the deal was bound to dilute profits because CA would probably have to borrow as much as $1 billion for the purchase, raising interest expense.
